intro: Baccharoides tolypophora, commonly known as the sand cordgrass, is a flowering plant native to the coastal regions of the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Poaceae family, which includes grasses, and is characterized by its tufted growth habit and narrow, linear leaves. The plant typically grows in sandy or muddy soils along tidal zones, showcasing its adaptability to saline and fluctuating water conditions. Its small, clustered inflorescences produce wind-pollinated flowers, contributing to its role in coastal ecosystems. Baccharoides tolypophora plays an important ecological role in stabilizing dunes and providing habitat for various coastal species.
